instruction: Who is Frank Lloyd Wright, and why is he famous?
input:
Frank Lloyd Wright (June 8, 1867 – April 9, 1959) was an American architect, designer, writer, and educator.

He designed more than 1,000 structures over a creative period of 70 years. Wright played a key role in the architectural movements of the twentieth century, influencing architects worldwide through his works and hundreds of apprentices in his Taliesin Fellowship. Wright believed in designing in harmony with humanity and the environment, a philosophy he called organic architecture. This philosophy was exemplified in Fallingwater (1935), which has been called "the best all-time work of American architecture".

Wright was the pioneer of what came to be called the Prairie School movement of architecture and also developed the concept of the Usonian home in Broadacre City, his vision for urban planning in the United States. He also designed original and innovative offices, churches, schools, skyscrapers, hotels, museums, and other commercial projects. Wright-designed interior elements (including leaded glass windows, floors, furniture and even tableware) were integrated into these structures. He wrote several books and numerous articles and was a popular lecturer in the United States and in Europe. Wright was recognized in 1991 by the American Institute of Architects as "the greatest American architect of all time". In 2019, a selection of his work became a listed World Heritage Site as The 20th-Century Architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright.

Raised in rural Wisconsin, Wright studied civil engineering at the University of Wisconsin and then apprenticed in Chicago, briefly with Joseph Lyman Silsbee, and then with Louis Sullivan at Adler & Sullivan. Wright opened his own successful Chicago practice in 1893 and established a studio in his Oak Park, Illinois home in 1898. His fame increased and his personal life sometimes made headlines: leaving his first wife Catherine Tobin for Mamah Cheney in 1909; the murder of Mamah and her children and others at his Taliesin estate by a staff member in 1914; his tempestuous marriage with second wife Miriam Noel (m. 1923–1927); and his courtship and marriage with Olgivanna Lazović (m. 1928–1959).
output: Frank Lloyd Wright was an American architect, designer, writer, and educator. He is famous for his innovative architectural designs and his philosophy of organic architecture. Wright designed over 1,000 structures throughout his career, and his works have had a significant impact on the architectural movements of the twentieth century. He believed in designing in harmony with humanity and the environment, and his philosophy is evident in his most famous work, Fallingwater, which is considered one of the greatest works of American architecture. Wright also pioneered the Prairie School movement of architecture and developed the concept of the Usonian home. His designs included offices, churches, schools, skyscrapers, hotels, museums, and other commercial projects. He was recognized by the American Institute of Architects as the greatest American architect of all time. In 2019, a selection of his work became a listed World Heritage Site.
Frank Lloyd Wright continues to be an inspiration in architecture around the United States and many of his originally designed buildings and structures stand today.

instruction: How to get an efficient cardio workout and improve your speed, and gain other health benefits?
output:
To get an efficient cardio workout and improve your speed, there are a few key steps you can follow:

1. Choose the right exercises: Incorporate exercises that elevate your heart rate and engage large muscle groups. Examples include running, cycling, swimming, jumping rope, or using cardio machines like the elliptical or rowing machine.

2. Set goals: Determine what you want to achieve with your cardio workouts. Whether it's improving your speed, increasing endurance, or losing weight, having clear goals will help you stay focused and motivated.

3. Interval training: Incorporate interval training into your cardio routine. This involves alternating between high-intensity bursts of exercise and lower-intensity recovery periods. For example, you could sprint for 30 seconds, followed by a 1-minute jog, and repeat for a set number of rounds.

4. Gradually increase intensity: As your fitness level improves, gradually increase the intensity of your workouts. This could involve running faster, cycling at a higher resistance, or increasing the incline on the treadmill. Pushing yourself out of your comfort zone will help you see progress.

5. Cross-training: Incorporate different types of cardio exercises into your routine to challenge your body in different ways. This can help prevent boredom and reduce the risk of overuse injuries. For example, alternate between running, swimming, and cycling throughout the week.

6. Consistency: Consistency is key when it comes to improving your cardio fitness and speed. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity cardio exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity exercise per week. Spread your workouts throughout the week for optimal results.

7. Proper nutrition and rest: Fuel your body with a balanced diet that includes carbohydrates, protein, and healthy fats to support your workouts. Also, prioritize rest and recovery to allow your body to adapt and get stronger.

Remember to consult with a healthcare professional or certified fitness trainer before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any underlying health conditions or concerns.

In this day and age when many are busy with work, family, electronic gadgets, social media it becomes increasingly challenging to find the time to exercise.  Staying healthy will allow you to enjoy those distractions longer, but jokes aside it will make you feel energized, motivated and bring out the best in you.  When new discoveries in scenic areas are correctly applied, you don’t need to spend multiple hours at the gym, you don’t have to starve to achieve your goals, this concept was very enticing to me when I first learnt about the Sprint 8 program at my local gym.  I decided to give this a try!

Sprint 8 - Its a 20 minute routine, where you spend the first 30 seconds working out at the highest level of intensity (go all out) followed by 90 seconds of active recovery, repeat this 8 times..  You can use a bike, treadmill, elliptical whichever suits your style.  In all my life of being fairly active, Sprint 8 has the toughest workout, but over a year I could see significant results.  I was able to run faster, lower blood pressure, reduce fat percentage, and improve muscle mass.  The key differentiator about this program is that it engages all the three muscle fiber types and releases exercise induced growth hormones to help your body become stronger, leaner and healthier.

Another advantage is that this program really reduces any change of injury that one may face by running, heavy weight lifting etc therefore allowing you to sustain the exercise program for years to come.  

Give this a try and gain the benefits of efficient exercising.

instruction: Given a reference text about Georg Friedrich Parrot, tell me when and where he was born as well as what he studied.

Education
Georges-Frédéric Parrot was born in Mömpelgard (now Montbéliard) (then part of the Duchy of Württemberg, from 1806 in France). His father, a surgeon by profession and the local duke's physician in ordinary, had a respectable position in the society becoming the mayor of his hometown. As the family was Protestants, they sent Georg Friedrich to study physics and mathematics at the University of Stuttgart in Stuttgart, the capital of the Duchy (1782–1786).
output: Georg Friedrich Parrot was born on 15 July 1767 in Mömpelgard, which is now known as Montbéliard. At the time, it was part of the Duchy of Württemberg and later became a part of France in 1806. He studied physics and mathematics at the University of Stuttgart in Stuttgart, the capital of the Duchy, from 1782 to 1786.
Georg Friedrich Parrot was born on July 15, 1767 in Mömpelgard. He studied physics and mathematics at the University of Stuttgart.

instruction: Snow or Desert

Snow and desert are two contrasting environments with distinct characteristics.

Snow:

- Snow is white in color and can create a beautiful and serene landscape.
- Snow can be enjoyed for various recreational activities such as skiing, snowboarding, snowball fights, and building snowmen.
- However, snow can also cause difficulties, such as travel disruptions, slippery roads, and the need for extra precautions to stay warm and safe.

Desert:
- A desert is a barren, arid region with little to no vegetation and limited water sources.
- Deserts are typically characterized by high temperatures during the day and cold temperatures at night.
- Deserts can be sandy, rocky, or a combination of both, depending on the specific type of desert.
- Deserts are home to unique flora and fauna that have adapted to survive in harsh conditions, such as cacti and camels.
- Despite the harsh conditions, deserts can offer stunning landscapes and opportunities for activities such as dune bashing, camel riding, and stargazing.

Both snow and desert environments have their own appeal and can offer different experiences depending on personal preferences and interests.

instruction: Summarize in one sentence this article about a famous song.
input:
"I'm an Old Cowhand (From the Rio Grande)" is a comic song written by Johnny Mercer for the Paramount Pictures release Rhythm on the Range and sung by its star, Bing Crosby. The Crosby commercial recording was made on July 17, 1936, with Jimmy Dorsey & his Orchestra for Decca Records. It was a huge hit in 1936, reaching the No. 2 spot in the charts of the day, and it greatly furthered Mercer's career. Crosby recorded the song again in 1954 for his album Bing: A Musical Autobiography.
Members of the Western Writers of America chose it as one of the Top 100 Western songs of all time.

Background
Mercer and his wife were driving across the US en route to his hometown, Savannah, Georgia, after having apparently failed to succeed in Hollywood. Mercer was amused by the sight of cowboys, with spurs and ten-gallon hats, driving cars and trucks instead of riding horses. Singing cowboys were popular in films and on the radio then, and within 15 minutes, writing on the back of an envelope, Mercer transferred the image he was seeing into a song whose satirical lyrics vented some of his own bitter frustration with Hollywood.

The lyrics, about a 20th-century cowboy who has little in common with the cowpunchers of old, have been included in some anthologies of light verse.
output: "I'm an Old Cowhand (From the Rio Grande)" is a comic song written by Johnny Mercer, sung by Bing Crosby, and recorded in 1936, which became a huge hit and furthered Mercer's career, and was later chosen as one of the Top 100 Western songs of all time by the Western Writers of America.
I'm an Old Cowhand (From the Rio Grande), written by Johnny Mercer and recorded by Bing Crosby, is popular song from 1936 that satirizes cowboy culture of the time.

instruction: How does the Harvard housing system work?
output: First-Year students live in one of the seventeen dormitories located in and around Harvard Yard. Rooms are assigned based on a brief survey sent to admitted students. The survey asks questions like “How many roommates do you want?”, “How comfortable are you with noise?”, and “What type of music do you listen to?”. After the first year, the majority of students move into one of the twelve residential Houses. Houses are assigned in March of a student’s first year. Rather than randomly assigning individual students to houses and scattering close friends, students can assemble into “blocking groups” of no greater than 8 students and each group is randomly assigned to a House. If 8 friends aren’t enough, two blocking groups can link themselves in the lottery. Linked groups will not be assigned the same House but are guaranteed to be assigned the same Neighborhood (e.g. The Quad).

The Harvard housing system is a unique residential system that is designed to provide students with a sense of community and support during their time at Harvard University. Under this system, all undergraduate students are assigned to one of the 12 residential houses on campus.

Each residential house has its own distinct character and offers a variety of amenities, including dining halls, common spaces, and facilities for social, cultural, and academic activities. Students live in dormitory-style rooms within their assigned house.

The housing assignment is typically random, but students have the opportunity to indicate their preferences during the housing application process. Once assigned to a house, students become part of a close-knit community and have the opportunity to engage in house-specific traditions, events, and activities.

The Harvard housing system aims to foster a sense of belonging and encourage interaction among students from diverse backgrounds. It provides a supportive environment for personal and intellectual growth, and many students form lasting friendships and connections through their residential house experiences.

instruction: I'm confused as to which of these food staples have gluten and which are gluten-free. From this list can you tell me which is which: Pasta, rice, potatoes, noodles and bread.

- Rice: Rice is naturally gluten-free and does not contain any gluten proteins.

- Potatoes: Potatoes are also naturally gluten-free and do not contain gluten.

Remember, if you have specific dietary needs or restrictions, it's always a good idea to check the labels or consult with a healthcare professional to ensure the products you choose are gluten-free.

instruction: What are some of the reasons people like to visit Brazil?
output:
There are many reasons why people like to visit Brazil. Here are a few popular ones:

1. Beautiful Beaches: Brazil is known for its stunning coastline, with famous beaches like Copacabana and Ipanema in Rio de Janeiro. These beaches offer picturesque views, warm weather, and a vibrant beach culture.

2. Cultural Diversity: Brazil is a melting pot of different cultures, which can be seen in its music, dance, art, and food. The country's rich cultural heritage, influenced by African, European, and Indigenous traditions, makes it a fascinating destination for those interested in exploring diverse cultures.

3. Amazon Rainforest: Brazil is home to a significant portion of the Amazon rainforest, which is the largest tropical rainforest in the world. Many visitors are drawn to Brazil to experience the unique flora and fauna found in this biodiverse ecosystem.

4. Carnival: Brazil is famous for its vibrant Carnival celebrations, which take place annually in cities like Rio de Janeiro and Salvador. Carnival is a lively festival filled with music, dance, and colorful parades, attracting tourists from all over the world.

5. Outdoor Activities: Brazil offers a wide range of outdoor activities for adventure enthusiasts. From hiking in the mountains of Chapada Diamantina to surfing in Florianopolis, there are plenty of opportunities to enjoy nature and engage in thrilling adventures.

6. Historical and Architectural Marvels: Brazil is home to several UNESCO World Heritage sites, including the historic center of Salvador and the iconic Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro. These architectural marvels provide a glimpse into Brazil's rich history and offer stunning views of the surrounding areas.

These are just a few of the many reasons why people enjoy visiting Brazil. The country's diverse attractions, warm hospitality, and vibrant culture make it a popular destination for travelers from around the world.

Brazil is a South American country with a diverse landscape and cultural mix. From subtropical grasslands in the South to drier biomes in the northeast to the Amazon rainforest, many people visit the country to experience one of the world's biodiverse hotspots. Several species are endemic to Brazil, particularly in the Amazon region. The country is also known for a culture that blends European, African and Indigenous influences. Many visitors are intrigued by its diverse culture. The nation received many migrants from all over the world in the 19th and 20th centuries, leading to the largest Japanese community outside of Japan, largest Italian population outside of Italy, and the largest population of  SubSaharan African descent outside of Nigeria. Many of the cultural expressions of Brazil - capoeira, the large Carnaval parades, Brazilian soccer and jiu-jitsu - have found a devotees outside of the country.

instruction: how is white rice made?

White rice is has no nutritional value because the nutrition has been stripped from it during the production process of making white rice.

instruction: Does structured streaming support joins?

instruction: What would happen if I ran barefoot? Is it good for me?
output:
Running barefoot can have both benefits and potential drawbacks. Here are some things to consider:

Benefits:
1. Strengthening foot muscles: Running without shoes can help strengthen the muscles in your feet, as they have to work harder to provide stability and support.
2. Improving balance and proprioception: Running barefoot can enhance your body's awareness of its position and movement, improving balance and coordination.
3. Natural running form: Some argue that running barefoot encourages a more natural running form, with a midfoot or forefoot strike rather than a heel strike.

Potential Drawbacks:
1. Risk of injury: Running without shoes increases the risk of stepping on sharp objects, glass, or rough surfaces that can cause cuts, bruises, or puncture wounds.
2. Lack of cushioning: Shoes provide cushioning and shock absorption, which can help reduce impact on joints and muscles. Running barefoot may lead to increased stress on these areas.
3. Adaptation period: If you're used to running with shoes, transitioning to barefoot running should be done gradually to allow your body to adapt to the increased demands on the feet and lower legs.

It's important to note that the suitability of barefoot running varies from person to person. If you're considering running barefoot, it's advisable to consult with a healthcare professional or a sports specialist who can evaluate your individual circumstances and provide personalized advice.

Running barefoot tends to shift the striking point of the foot to the balls of the feet, rather than the heels as people commonly do while wearing shoes. Some evidence shows that this front foot-first pattern can reduce the risk of many running-related injuries. However, running barefoot is also more painful, especially on rough terrain or in the cold. Therefore, most people opt to run while wearing shoes.

instruction: What are the advatages and disadvatages of commuting with bikes comparing to cars?
output:
Commuting with bikes compared to cars has several advantages and disadvantages. 

Advantages of commuting with bikes:
1. Health benefits: Biking is a great form of exercise that can improve cardiovascular health, build muscle strength, and help with weight management.
2. Cost-effective: Biking is generally cheaper than driving a car, as it eliminates the need for fuel, parking fees, and vehicle maintenance costs.
3. Environmentally friendly: Biking produces zero emissions, making it a sustainable and eco-friendly mode of transportation that helps reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.
4. Avoiding traffic: Bikes can often maneuver through traffic more easily, especially in congested urban areas, saving time and frustration.
5. Parking convenience: Bikes require less space to park, making it easier to find parking spots and reducing the time spent looking for parking.

Disadvantages of commuting with bikes:
1. Limited carrying capacity: Bikes have limited space for carrying groceries, luggage, or other large items, which may be a challenge for some commuters.
2. Weather dependency: Inclement weather conditions, such as rain, snow, or extreme heat, can make biking uncomfortable or unsafe.
3. Safety concerns: Bicycles are more vulnerable to accidents and collisions with cars, and cyclists may be exposed to greater risks on the road.
4. Longer travel times: Biking may take longer than driving a car, especially for longer distances or when there are no dedicated bike lanes or paths available.
5. Limited accessibility: Biking may not be a viable option for individuals with physical disabilities, health conditions, or those who live in areas with limited bike infrastructure.

It's important to consider these factors and choose the mode of transportation that best suits your needs and circumstances.

There are several advantages that matter a lot to me personally. Bikes are much cheaper than cars, and don't require subsequent payment for gas and insurance. Finding a parking space and paying for parking can also be a concern for cars. Commuting by bicycle for half an hour to an hour every day can relax my mind. As for the disadvantages, I can bike with caltrain/bart to commute between different cities, but it is inevitably slower than driving. Also, rainy days are very unfriendly to biking, which happens a lot these days.

instruction: Without quoting directly from the text give me a summary of the history of the Key Lime Pie.
input:
Key lime pie is probably derived from the "Magic Lemon Cream Pie" published in a promotional brochure by Borden, a producer of condensed milk, in 1931. The recipe is attributed to Borden's fictional spokesperson, Jane Ellison, and includes condensed milk, lemon juice and rind, and egg yolks. It is covered with meringue, baked, and served cold. According to the pastry chef Stella Parks, users of the recipe altered it with local ingredients; she describes it as "a stunning reminder of how deeply America's traditions are shaped by advertising".

A "Tropical Lime Chiffon Pie", using condensed milk and egg yolks, is documented in a 1933 Miami newspaper article. An "icebox lime pie", was mentioned as a specialty of the Florida Keys in 1935.[full citation needed] and a recipe under the name "Key Lime Pie" was published in 1940.[full citation needed]

No earlier solid sources are known, despite appeals to the public. A 1927 Key West Women's Club cookbook does not mention the recipe. A 1926 restaurant menu includes "lime pie", but it is unclear what it was. Various accounts claim that it was known earlier, but none were recorded before 1933. A widely-reported story claims that William Curry's cook Aunt Sally invented it in the late 19th century. But there is no evidence for this, and the oldest version of this story dates to only 1895, in promotional materials for a Bed and Breakfast in Curry's former house.

It was in the 1950s that Key lime pie was promoted as Florida's "most famous treat" and in 1987 as "the greatest of all regional American desserts."
output:
Key lime pie has a history that can be traced back to the early 20th century. It is believed to have been derived from a recipe called "Magic Lemon Cream Pie" published by Borden, a condensed milk producer, in 1931. The recipe included condensed milk, lemon juice and rind, and egg yolks, and was covered with meringue, baked, and served cold. 

In 1933, a newspaper article documented a similar pie called "Tropical Lime Chiffon Pie" that used condensed milk and egg yolks. By 1935, an "icebox lime pie" was mentioned as a specialty of the Florida Keys. The first known published recipe under the name "Key Lime Pie" appeared in 1940.

Despite efforts to find earlier sources, no solid evidence of the pie's existence before the 1930s has been found. A 1927 Key West Women's Club cookbook does not mention the recipe, and a 1926 restaurant menu includes "lime pie," but it is unclear what that referred to. There are claims that the pie was known earlier, with one story suggesting that it was invented by William Curry's cook Aunt Sally in the late 19th century. However, there is no evidence to support this claim, and the oldest version of this story dates back to only 1895 in promotional materials for a Bed and Breakfast in Curry's former house.

In the 1950s, Key lime pie started to be promoted as Florida's "most famous treat," and in 1987, it was hailed as "the greatest of all regional American desserts."

Key lime pie is an American dessert pie. It is made of lime juice, egg yolks, and sweetened condensed milk. It is best served with meringue topping and is typically cooked in a graham cracker crust.

The dish is named after the small Key limes which which have yellow juice complementing the filling which is typically yellow because of the egg yolks used.

The filling is made by simply mixing the ingredients without cooking the proteins of the egg yolks and condensed milk and the acidic lime juice curdle, thickening the mixture without baking.

instruction: When and why was the plaxton coach production halted?
input:
By 1936 the company felt justified in constructing a large new manufacturing facility in Seamer Road, Scarborough. This allowed increased production, and Plaxtons became popular with many independent operators throughout Northern England. Many of these operators purchased their vehicles through independent dealers, rather than directly from the factory. In this regard, Plaxton's sales were through Lancashire Motor Traders Ltd of Manchester and Arlington Motor Co Ltd of London. The company became known as FW Plaxton & Son by 1937, as the founder's son, also named Frederick William joined the company at the age of 18. FW Plaxton junior was to be known as Eric to avoid confusion with his father.

Plaxtons built a number of different coach designs through the 1930s, until settling on a distinctive house style. The style typically consisted of a very rounded front profile at the windscreen area with side windows that sloped backwards at the front, were upright at the centre, and sloped forward at the back. Bodywork for the Bedford WTB chassis was particularly distinctive, sloping severally from the bottom of the front wheel arch to the roofline, leaving the "bullnose" radiator grille protruding. The rear also sloped prominently. The WTB chassis was very popular choice for operators at that time, together with the Dodge RBF and SBF. Leyland and AEC chassis were also popular for larger coaches, notably the Leyland Tiger and AEC Regal.

On the outbreak of World War II in 1939, coach production halted and the factory was turned into a munitions factory under the control of the Ministry of Aircraft Production. Many records from the early years were lost when an incendiary bomb set fire to the Seamer Road factory in 1943, causing much damage. As the factory was under control of the Ministry of Works, production continued in the open air whilst a replacement was constructed. Some adjacent land was loaned by a market gardener who subsequently joined the board years later.
output: The Plaxton coach production was halted in 1939 due to the outbreak of World War II. The factory was converted into a munitions factory under the control of the Ministry of Aircraft Production. The production of coaches was suspended during the war, and the factory was damaged by an incendiary bomb in 1943. Production resumed after the war once a replacement factory was constructed.
Coach production was halted in 1939 due to world war outbreak. The factory was turned into munitions factory.

instruction: Given this passage from wikipedia about the attributes of Japanese Anime, summarize the key differences between Japanese anime and other forms of animation
input:
Anime differs from other forms of animation by its art styles, methods of animation, its production, and its process. Visually, anime works exhibit a wide variety of art styles, differing between creators, artists, and studios. While no single art style predominates anime as a whole, they do share some similar attributes in terms of animation technique and character design.

Anime is fundamentally characterized by the use of limited animation, flat expression, the suspension of time, its thematic range, the presence of historical figures, its complex narrative line and, above all, a peculiar drawing style, with characters characterized by large and oval eyes, with very defined lines, bright colors and reduced movement of the lips

The cinematic effects of anime differentiates itself from the stage plays found in American animation. Anime is cinematically shot as if by camera, including panning, zooming, distance and angle shots to more complex dynamic shots that would be difficult to produce in reality. In anime, the animation is produced before the voice acting, contrary to American animation which does the voice acting first.
output:
Japanese anime differs from other forms of animation in several ways. 

Firstly, anime exhibits a wide variety of art styles, with different creators, artists, and studios having their own unique styles. While there is no single dominant art style in anime, there are some common attributes in terms of animation technique and character design.

Secondly, anime is characterized by the use of limited animation, flat expression, and the suspension of time. It also has a wide thematic range, often featuring historical figures and complex narrative lines. One distinctive feature of anime is its peculiar drawing style, with characters typically having large and oval eyes, defined lines, bright colors, and reduced movement of the lips.

Thirdly, the cinematic effects in anime set it apart from American animation, which is more reminiscent of stage plays. Anime employs various cinematic techniques such as panning, zooming, distance and angle shots, as well as more complex dynamic shots that would be difficult to produce in reality.

Lastly, the production process of anime differs from American animation. In anime, the animation is typically produced before the voice acting, whereas in American animation, the voice acting is usually done first.

Anime separates itself from other forms of animation through its depiction of characters, as well as portrayal of cinematic effects. Characters in anime are often drawn with very well defined features, highlighted by bold lines and bright colors, along with large oval eyes. Cinematic effects are often highlighted by dynamic shots, including panning, zooming, angle shots, as if the scene was shot on a camera.

instruction: What are the common formats of competitive debate in the US?
output:
In the United States, there are several common formats of competitive debate. Some of the most popular formats include:

1. Policy Debate: Also known as Cross-Examination Debate, this format focuses on debating a specific policy proposal. Teams argue for or against the resolution by presenting evidence and engaging in cross-examination.

2. Lincoln-Douglas Debate: Named after the famous debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, this format is a one-on-one debate that focuses on values, ethics, and philosophy. It typically involves a resolution that debaters argue for or against.

3. Public Forum Debate: This format is designed to simulate a public debate and is often more accessible to a wider audience. It involves teams of two debating a current events topic, with a focus on persuasive speaking and argumentation.

4. Parliamentary Debate: This format is modeled after the British parliamentary system. It involves teams of two or four debaters arguing for or against a motion. Debaters have limited preparation time and must think on their feet.

These are just a few examples of the common debate formats in the United States. Each format has its own rules and structure, but they all aim to promote critical thinking, persuasive communication, and the ability to construct well-reasoned arguments.

- Public Forum
- Lincoln-Douglas
- Policy
- Congressional Debate
- British Parliamentary 
- World Schools Debate
- International Public Policy Forum

instruction: What are some good kids activities on Lake Norman, NC?
output:
Lake Norman, NC offers a variety of fun activities for kids. Here are some suggestions:

1. Lake activities: Kids can enjoy swimming, boating, fishing, and kayaking on Lake Norman. There are several rental companies that offer watercrafts for families to enjoy.

2. Lake Norman State Park: This park offers hiking trails, picnic areas, and a sandy beach for swimming. Kids can explore nature, have a picnic, or play in the water.

3. Discovery Place Kids: Located in Huntersville, Discovery Place Kids is a hands-on children's museum with interactive exhibits, educational programs, and play areas. It's a great place for kids to learn and have fun.

4. Jetton Park: This park features a playground, picnic areas, walking trails, and a beach area. Kids can enjoy playing on the playground equipment, feeding ducks, or having a picnic.

5. Carolina Raptor Center: Located in Huntersville, this center is dedicated to the conservation of birds of prey. Kids can learn about different bird species and even see live raptor presentations.

6. Rural Hill: This historic site offers various activities for kids, including corn mazes, hayrides, and farm animals. It's a great place for families to spend a day outdoors.

Remember to check the operating hours, availability, and any specific guidelines or restrictions for each activity before planning your visit.

Lake Norman offers activities for a range of different ages/interests. If you're looking to spend time near the waters edge, you can visit one of the many town and state parks that border the lake: Jetton Park - Cornelius, Lake Norman State Park - Troutman, Ramsey Creek Park - Cornelius are a few options. You can also hire a boat for the day and enjoy fishing, water sports, or cruising. There are several small islands on the lake that are free for public use, where you can find small beaches to pull up and picnic/play in the sand. The water temperature of the lake during the summer months is generally warm and children should enjoy swimming and splashing in the water.

instruction: Why should one travel the world?
output:
There are many reasons why one should travel the world. Here are a few:

1. Cultural immersion: Traveling allows you to experience different cultures, traditions, and customs firsthand. It broadens your perspective and helps you gain a better understanding and appreciation for diversity.

2. Personal growth: Traveling pushes you out of your comfort zone and challenges you to adapt to new environments. It helps you develop valuable life skills such as problem-solving, communication, and independence.

3. Learning opportunities: Exploring different countries and interacting with locals provides unique learning opportunities. You can learn about history, art, cuisine, languages, and more.

4. Building connections: Traveling allows you to meet people from different backgrounds and build meaningful connections. It can lead to lifelong friendships and valuable networking opportunities.

5. Self-discovery: Traveling gives you the chance to step away from your daily routine and discover more about yourself. It can help you gain clarity, find new passions, and redefine your priorities.

6. Adventure and excitement: Traveling offers endless opportunities for adventure and excitement. Whether it's hiking in breathtaking landscapes, trying new activities, or exploring hidden gems, there's always something exciting to discover.

7. Appreciation for nature: Traveling allows you to witness the beauty of the natural world, from stunning landscapes to diverse wildlife. It can deepen your appreciation for the environment and inspire you to become a responsible global citizen.

Remember, everyone's reasons for traveling may vary, and it's important to prioritize your own interests and goals when planning your adventures.

As the son of a U.S. Diplomat, I've had the opportunity to live abroad most of my life in countries such as Cambodia, Australia, South Korea and Malaysia. Through my travels despite the sad goodbyes to friends and family, I learned the importance of being open-minded, resilient and open to a diverse network. When you travel abroad you experience a world you may have never considered or a culture that shows you the diversity of the world. This is important for personal development.

instruction: What is Passover?
output: Passover is a Jewish holiday that commemorates the liberation of the Israelites from slavery in ancient Egypt. It is observed for seven or eight days, depending on the Jewish tradition. During Passover, families gather for a special meal called the Seder, where they retell the story of the Exodus and eat symbolic foods. The holiday is marked by various rituals, including the removal of leavened bread from the home, the eating of unleavened bread called matzah, and the drinking of four cups of wine. Passover is an important and widely observed holiday in the Jewish faith.
Passover is a major Jewish holiday that celebrates the Biblical story of the Israelites' escape from slavery in Egypt.

Rooted in skiffle, beat and 1950s rock 'n' roll, their sound incorporated elements of classical music and traditional pop in innovative ways; the band also explored music styles ranging from folk and Indian music to psychedelia and hard rock. As pioneers in recording, songwriting and artistic presentation, the Beatles revolutionised many aspects of the music industry and were often publicised as leaders of the era's youth and sociocultural movements

instruction: What is an interchange fee?
output:
Interchange fee is a term used in the payment card industry to describe a fee paid between banks for the acceptance of card-based transactions. Usually for sales/services transactions it is a fee that a merchant's bank (the "acquiring bank") pays a customer's bank (the "issuing bank").

In a credit card or debit card transaction, the card-issuing bank in a payment transaction deducts the interchange fee from the amount it pays the acquiring bank that handles a credit or debit card transaction for a merchant. The acquiring bank then pays the merchant the amount of the transaction minus both the interchange fee and an additional, usually smaller, fee for the acquiring bank or independent sales organization (ISO), which is often referred to as a discount rate, an add-on rate, or passthru. For cash withdrawal transactions at ATMs, however, the fees are paid by the card-issuing bank to the acquiring bank (for the maintenance of the machine).

An interchange fee is a fee that is charged to merchants by banks or credit card processors for accepting credit or debit card payments. It is typically a percentage of the transaction amount and is paid by the merchant to the card issuer as compensation for the transaction processing services provided. The interchange fee covers the costs associated with processing the payment, including fraud prevention, transaction authorization, and settlement.

instruction: What is Chianti wine? What kind of grape it is?
input:
A Chianti wine (/kiˈænti/, also US: /-ˈɑːn-/, Italian: [ˈkjanti]) is any wine produced in the Chianti region of central Tuscany. It was historically associated with a squat bottle enclosed in a straw basket, called a fiasco ("flask"; pl. fiaschi). However, the fiasco is only used by a few makers of the wine as most Chianti is now bottled in more standard shaped wine bottles. In the mid-late 19th century, Baron Bettino Ricasoli (later Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Italy) helped establish Sangiovese as the blend's dominant grape variety, creating the blueprint for today's Chianti wines.

The first definition of a wine area called Chianti was made in 1716. It described the area near the villages of Gaiole, Castellina and Radda; the so-called Lega del Chianti and later Provincia del Chianti (Chianti province). In 1932 the Chianti area was completely redrawn and divided into seven sub-areas: Classico, Colli Aretini, Colli Fiorentini, Colline Pisane, Colli Senesi, Montalbano and Rùfina. Most of the villages that in 1932 were added to the newly defined Chianti Classico region added in Chianti to their names, for example Greve in Chianti, which amended its name in 1972. Wines labelled Chianti Classico come from the largest sub-area of Chianti, which includes the original Chianti heartland. Only Chianti from this sub-zone may display the black rooster (gallo nero) seal on the neck of the bottle, which indicates that the producer of the wine is a member of the Chianti Classico Consortium, the local association of producers. Other variants, with the exception of Rufina north-east of Florence and Montalbano south of Pistoia, originate in the named provinces: Siena for the Colli Senesi, Florence for the Colli Fiorentini, Arezzo for the Colli Aretini and Pisa for the Colline Pisane. In 1996 part of the Colli Fiorentini sub-area was renamed Montespertoli.

During the 1970s producers started to reduce the quantity of white grapes in Chianti. In 1995 it became legal to produce a Chianti with 100% Sangiovese. For a wine to retain the name of Chianti it must be produced with at least 80% Sangiovese grapes. Aged Chianti (38 months instead of 4–7) may be labelled as Riserva. Chianti that meets more stringent requirements (lower yield, higher alcohol content and dry extract) may be labelled as Chianti Superiore, although Chianti from the Classico sub-area is not allowed in any event to be labelled as Superiore.
output:
Chianti wine is a type of wine produced in the Chianti region of central Tuscany, Italy. It is historically associated with a squat bottle enclosed in a straw basket, called a fiasco. However, most Chianti is now bottled in more standard shaped wine bottles. 

The dominant grape variety used in Chianti wine is Sangiovese. In the mid-late 19th century, Baron Bettino Ricasoli helped establish Sangiovese as the blend's dominant grape variety, creating the blueprint for today's Chianti wines.

There are different sub-areas within the Chianti region, including Chianti Classico, Colli Aretini, Colli Fiorentini, Colline Pisane, Colli Senesi, Montalbano, and Rùfina. Each sub-area has its own characteristics and regulations for wine production.

Chianti Classico is the largest sub-area and includes the original Chianti heartland. Wines labeled Chianti Classico may display the black rooster (gallo nero) seal on the neck of the bottle, indicating that the producer is a member of the Chianti Classico Consortium.

To be called Chianti, the wine must be produced with at least 80% Sangiovese grapes. Aged Chianti may be labeled as Riserva, and Chianti that meets more stringent requirements may be labeled as Chianti Superiore. However, Chianti from the Classico sub-area is not allowed to be labeled as Superiore.

Chianti wine is any kind of wine made in the Chianti region of Tuscany, Italy. Sangiovese is the dominant variety of the grape used in Chianti wines. To call it a Chianti wine, it must be produced with at least 80% Sangiovese grapes.

instruction: What are all the books in the Lord of the Rings trilogy?
input: Although often called a trilogy, the work was intended by Tolkien to be one volume of a two-volume set along with The Silmarillion.[T 3] For economic reasons, The Lord of the Rings was published over the course of a year from 29 July 1954 to 20 October 1955 in three volumes titled The Fellowship of the Ring, The Two Towers, and The Return of the King. The work is divided internally into six books, two per volume, with several appendices of background material. Some later editions print the entire work in a single volume, following the author's original intent.
output:
The Lord of the Rings is often referred to as a trilogy, but it was originally intended by J.R.R. Tolkien to be one volume of a two-volume set, along with The Silmarillion. However, for economic reasons, it was published as a trilogy over the course of a year from July 29, 1954, to October 20, 1955. The three volumes are titled:

1. The Fellowship of the Ring
2. The Two Towers
3. The Return of the King

Each volume contains two books, making a total of six books in the entire work. Additionally, there are several appendices included in some editions that provide background material. Some later editions do print the entire work in a single volume, which aligns with the author's original intent.
The Lord of the Rings trilogy is comprised of: The Fellowship of the Ring, The Two Towers and The Return of the King.

instruction: What types of Barbecue (BBQ) are there?
output:
There are various types of barbecue (BBQ) styles that are popular in different regions of the world. Some of the most well-known types include:

1. American Barbecue: This style is prevalent in the United States and has regional variations such as Texas-style, Kansas City-style, Carolina-style, and Memphis-style barbecue. Each style has its own unique flavors, meat cuts, and sauce preferences.

2. Korean Barbecue: Known as "Gogi-gui," Korean barbecue involves grilling marinated meat, typically beef, pork, or chicken, at the table. It is often accompanied by various side dishes like kimchi, rice, and sauces.

3. Brazilian Barbecue: Also known as "Churrasco," Brazilian barbecue is famous for its skewered meats cooked over an open flame. It includes various cuts of beef, pork, lamb, and chicken, seasoned with rock salt and served with chimichurri sauce.

4. Argentine Barbecue: Similar to Brazilian barbecue, Argentine barbecue, known as "Asado," involves grilling various meats, particularly beef, over an open fire. It is often served with chimichurri sauce and enjoyed with friends and family.

5. Japanese Barbecue: Known as "Yakiniku," Japanese barbecue involves grilling bite-sized pieces of meat, including beef, pork, and chicken, on a charcoal or gas grill. It is enjoyed with dipping sauces and often includes vegetables and seafood.

These are just a few examples of the diverse barbecue styles found around the world. Each style has its own unique techniques, flavors, and cultural significance.

In America there are five distinct types of regional BBQ: Texas, Memphis, Kansas City, North Carolina, and South Carolina. Memphis and the Carolinas are known for the pork, Texas for their beef, and Kansas City for a variety of both.

instruction: What are the Fallas in Spain?

During the Fallas, large and elaborate sculptures made of wood and papier-mâché, called "fallas," are displayed throughout the city. These fallas often depict satirical or humorous scenes and are created by local artists. On the final day of the festival, the fallas are set on fire in a spectacular event known as "La Cremà." The Fallas is a significant cultural event in Spain, attracting visitors from all over the world.

Fallas happens every year in March in the Valencia region. The whole city is transformed into a large exposition of “Fallas” which stands for immense temporary statues. The word “Fallas” is also closely related the fire. During the celebration, every day you can hear the "Mascleta", thousand of firecrackers tied together explode in Dantesque noise just for the fun of feeling such beat, Fire is what closes the "Fallas", as all the statues will be burned to the ground and only one - publicly elected - will be saved.

instruction: What is a PCR test?
output: A PCR test, or Polymerase Chain Reaction test, is a type of diagnostic test used to detect the presence of genetic material, such as DNA or RNA, in a sample. It is commonly used in medical and research settings to identify and diagnose various diseases, including infectious diseases like COVID-19. The PCR test works by amplifying specific segments of the genetic material in the sample, allowing for its detection and analysis. This test is highly accurate and is considered the gold standard for diagnosing many diseases.

PCR stands for "polymerase chain reaction". This test uses cycles of heating and cooling to detect photons that are emitted when a reagent (binder) RNA binds to the viral RNA that has been extracted from the human sample. Each heating and cooling cycle increases (amplifies) the amount of the targeted genetic material in the test tube. If the intensity of the photons does not reach a threshold after a certain number of cycles, the PCR test will result in a "Not Detected" test result.

instruction: From this passage, extract the treatments for ACO in a bulleted list.
input:
Treatment of ACO is based on expert opinion as there are no universally accepted clinical guidelines. Treatment is usually based on whether clinical features of asthma or COPD predominate. Inhaled corticosteroids are the primary treatment in those with ACOS. Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) should be continued in those with asthma who develop decreased airway responsiveness to bronchodilators consistent with ACO. Therapy can be escalated to include a long acting beta-agonist (LABA) and inhaled steroid combination (ICS-LABA) or by adding on a long-acting anti-muscarinic inhaler (LAMA), known as triple therapy, in those with more severe or resistant disease.

Monoclonal antibodies targeting type 2 inflammation (which is predominant in asthma) have been used to treat severe asthma, and may also be used in severe cases of ACO. These monoclonal antibodies include omalizumab (an Anti-IgE antibody), mepolizumab (an anti-IL-5 antibody) and benralizumab (an anti-IL-5 receptor α antibody). People with ACOS and eosinophilia have a better response to ICS; with fewer exacerbations and hospitalizations seen in ACOS treated with long term ICS. Systemic corticosteroids (intravenous or oral steroids) may be used during exacerbations of ACOS.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asthma-COPD_overlap
output:
- Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are the primary treatment for ACOS.
- Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) should be continued in those with asthma who develop decreased airway responsiveness to bronchodilators consistent with ACO.
- Therapy can be escalated to include a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) and inhaled steroid combination (ICS-LABA) or by adding on a long-acting anti-muscarinic inhaler (LAMA), known as triple therapy, in those with more severe or resistant disease.
- Monoclonal antibodies targeting type 2 inflammation, such as omalizumab, mepolizumab, and benralizumab, may be used in severe cases of ACO.
- Systemic corticosteroids (intravenous or oral steroids) may be used during exacerbations of ACOS.

-Inhaled corticosteroids
-long acting beta-agonist (LABA) and inhaled steroid combination (ICS-LABA)
-triple therapy (in other words, adding on a long-acting anti-muscarinic inhaler (LAMA)
-monoclonal antibodies targeting type 2 inflammation
-systemic corticosteroids (intravenous or oral steroids)

instruction: What are the first and third eras of aircraft history mentioned in the text below and when did they end? Use a bullet list and the format {Name} ({Year}).
input:
Flying model craft and stories of manned flight go back many centuries; however, the first manned ascent — and safe descent — in modern times took place by larger hot-air balloons developed in the 18th century. Each of the two World Wars led to great technical advances. Consequently, the history of aircraft can be divided into five eras:

- Pioneers of flight, from the earliest experiments to 1914.
- First World War, 1914 to 1918.
- Aviation between the World Wars, 1918 to 1939.
- Second World War, 1939 to 1945.
- Postwar era, also called the Jet Age, 1945 to the present day.
output:
- Pioneers of flight (until 1914)
- Aviation between the World Wars (1918 to 1939)

- Pioneers of flight (1914)
- Aviation between the World Wars (1939)

instruction: What are a few things to do when visiting Northern Vietnam?
output:
When visiting Northern Vietnam, there are several things you can do to make the most of your trip. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Explore Hanoi: Start your trip by exploring the vibrant capital city of Hanoi. Visit the Old Quarter, Hoan Kiem Lake, and the Temple of Literature. Don't forget to try the delicious street food and experience the bustling night markets.

2. Take a cruise in Halong Bay: Halong Bay is a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its stunning limestone karsts and emerald waters. Take a cruise to explore the bay, visit floating villages, and enjoy activities like kayaking and swimming.

3. Trek in Sapa: Head to Sapa, a mountainous region in Northern Vietnam, for breathtaking landscapes and cultural experiences. Go on a trekking tour to visit ethnic minority villages, witness terraced rice fields, and enjoy the stunning views of the Hoang Lien Son mountain range.

4. Visit the Perfume Pagoda: Located about 60 kilometers southwest of Hanoi, the Perfume Pagoda is a complex of Buddhist temples built into the limestone cliffs. Take a boat ride along the scenic Yen River and hike up to the main temple for a spiritual experience.

5. Explore Ninh Binh: Known as the "Halong Bay on land," Ninh Binh offers beautiful landscapes of limestone mountains, rice fields, and river valleys. Take a boat ride through the Trang An Grottoes, visit the ancient capital of Hoa Lu, and explore the stunning Tam Coc-Bich Dong area.

6. Go trekking in Mai Chau: If you're looking for a more off-the-beaten-path experience, head to Mai Chau. This rural valley is surrounded by lush rice paddies and traditional stilt houses. Go trekking through the countryside, interact with ethnic minority groups, and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere.

Remember to respect the local culture, be mindful of the environment, and follow any guidelines or regulations set by local authorities.

Here are some to do when visiting Northern Vietnam: 
1. Go hiking through the picturesque rice terraces in Sa Pa. This is a great way to experience the beauty and local culture of Northern Vietnam.
2. Take a cruise on Ha Long Bay. This Unesco world heritage site is a great place to relax and take in the views as you sail through thousands of limestone islands.
3. Visit Hanoi and go on a food tour. This is one of the best ways to experience the local culture of Vietnam through authentic Vietnamese cuisine. 
4. Spend a day exploring the stunning landscapes of Ninh Binh. Home to the ancient capital of Vietnam and the Unesco World Heritage site of Trang An, Ninh Binh is a popular destination in Northern Vietnam.

instruction: What is a phenotype?
output:
In genetics and genomics, the phenotype  is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism. The term covers the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties, its behavior, and the products of behavior. An organism's phenotype results from two basic factors: the expression of an organism's genetic code (its genotype) and the influence of environmental factors. Both factors may interact, further affecting the phenotype. When two or more clearly different phenotypes exist in the same population of a species, the species is called polymorphic. A well-documented example of polymorphism is Labrador Retriever coloring; while the coat color depends on many genes, it is clearly seen in the environment as yellow, black, and brown. Richard Dawkins in 1978 and then again in his 1982 book The Extended Phenotype suggested that one can regard bird nests and other built structures such as caddisfly larva cases and beaver dams as "extended phenotypes".

Wilhelm Johannsen proposed the genotype–phenotype distinction in 1911 to make clear the difference between an organism's hereditary material and what that hereditary material produces. The distinction resembles that proposed by August Weismann (1834–1914), who distinguished between germ plasm (heredity) and somatic cells (the body). More recently, in The Selfish Gene (1976), Dawkins distinguished these concepts as replicators and vehicles.

The genotype–phenotype distinction should not be confused with Francis Crick's central dogma of molecular biology, a statement about the directionality of molecular sequential information flowing from DNA to protein, and not the reverse.

A phenotype refers to the observable physical or biochemical characteristics of an organism, which are determined by its genetic makeup (genotype) and influenced by environmental factors. It includes traits such as eye color, height, and behavior. Phenotypes are the result of the interaction between an organism's genes and the environment.

instruction: Given this paragraph about Freddie Mercury, where was his last performance with Queen.
input: Throughout his career, Mercury performed an estimated 700 concerts in countries around the world with Queen. A notable aspect of Queen concerts was the large scale involved. He once explained, "We're the Cecil B. DeMille of rock and roll, always wanting to do things bigger and better." The band was the first ever to play in South American stadiums, breaking worldwide records for concert attendance in the Morumbi Stadium in São Paulo in 1981. In 1986, Queen also played behind the Iron Curtain when they performed to a crowd of 80,000 in Budapest, in what was one of the biggest rock concerts ever held in Eastern Europe. Mercury's final live performance with Queen took place on 9 August 1986 at Knebworth Park in England and drew an attendance estimated as high as 200,000. A week prior to Knebworth, May recalled Mercury saying "I'm not going to be doing this forever. This is probably the last time." With the British national anthem "God Save the Queen" playing at the end of the concert, Mercury's final act on stage saw him draped in a robe, holding a golden crown aloft, bidding farewell to the crowd.
output: Freddie Mercury's last performance with Queen took place on 9 August 1986 at Knebworth Park in England. The concert drew an estimated attendance as high as 200,000 people.
Knebworth Park

instruction: What is XGBoost Algorithm?
output: XGBoost (eXtreme Gradient Boosting) is a machine learning algorithm that is widely used for supervised learning tasks, such as classification and regression. It is an implementation of the gradient boosting framework and is known for its speed and performance. XGBoost is designed to create a strong predictive model by combining the predictions of multiple weak models, such as decision trees, in an ensemble fashion. It uses gradient boosting to iteratively improve the model's accuracy by minimizing a specified loss function. XGBoost has gained popularity due to its ability to handle large datasets, handle missing values, and provide feature importance analysis.

XGBoost is a robust machine-learning algorithm that can help you understand your data and make better decisions. XGBoost is an implementation of gradient-boosting decision trees. It has been used by data scientists and researchers worldwide to optimize their machine-learning models. LightGBM is another common, related library for Gradient Boosting algorithm training. Both XGBoost and LightGBM are open-source and are used in a variety of Machine Learning tasks. LightGBM is generally faster for training on large datasets.

instruction: Describe the video game crash of 1983 in 2 sentences.
input:
The video game crash of 1983 (known as the Atari shock in Japan) was a large-scale recession in the video game industry that occurred from 1983 to 1985, primarily in the United States. The crash was attributed to several factors, including market saturation in the number of video game consoles and available games, many of which were of poor quality, as well as waning interest in console games in favor of personal computers. Home video game revenues peaked at around $3.2 billion in 1983, then fell to around $100 million by 1985 (a drop of almost 97 percent). The crash abruptly ended what is retrospectively considered the second generation of console video gaming in North America. To a lesser extent, the arcade video game market also weakened as the golden age of arcade video games came to an end.

Lasting about two years, the crash shook a then-booming video game industry and led to the bankruptcy of several companies producing home computers and video game consoles. Analysts of the time expressed doubts about the long-term viability of video game consoles and software.

The North American video game console industry recovered a few years later, mostly due to the widespread success of Nintendo's Western branding for its Famicom console, the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), released in 1985. The NES was designed to avoid the missteps that caused the 1983 crash and the stigma associated with video games at that time.
output: The video game crash of 1983 was a major recession in the video game industry, lasting from 1983 to 1985, primarily in the United States. It was caused by various factors, including market saturation, poor quality games, and a shift in interest towards personal computers. This crash led to the bankruptcy of several companies and raised doubts about the future of video game consoles and software. However, the industry eventually recovered with the success of Nintendo's NES console, which was designed to avoid the mistakes of the past.

Home video game revenues in North America declined from $3.2 billion in 1983 to around $100 million in 1985. This decline – which preceded the success of the Nintendo Entertainment System – is referred to as the video game crash of 1983.

instruction: Please give me a short summary of the critical response received by Season 1 of the Apple TV Series "Ted Lasso"
input:
Review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes reported an approval rating of 92% based on 74 reviews, with an average rating of 8.2/10. The website's critics consensus reads, "Warm and winsome, if not particularly hilarious, Ted Lasso fleshes out its promo premise with unrelenting optimism and a charming turn from Jason Sudeikis." Metacritic gave the first season a weighted average score of 71 out of 100 based on 21 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".

Kristen Baldwin of Entertainment Weekly gave the series an A− and wrote, "There's nothing groundbreaking about the way Ted Lasso's story beats play out, but the show—a mix of workplace antics, sentimental sports inspo, and soapy romance—is undeniably winning." Reviewing the series for Rolling Stone, Alan Sepinwall described the series as "extremely likable throughout, but it's more a hypothetical comedy than an actual one. There are long stretches where Juno Temple is the only actor even trying to sell what few jokes are in the scripts." and gave a rating of 3/5. Writing for The Guardian, Benjamin Lee gave it 2/5, describing it as "a show that isn't unwatchably bad but isn't really much of anything", and suggesting that some of its humor was "rooted in some questionable and uneasy stereotypes".

As the season went on, critical appreciation for the show increased. After the eighth episode aired, Caroline Framke of Variety published a review with the headline "For Your Reconsideration: Ted Lasso". She went on to say, "Above all odds, Ted Lasso chipped away at my skepticism until there was none left—just like the character himself does to everyone he meets", adding, "At a time when just about everything feels catastrophic, there's something undeniably satisfying about spending some time with good people who are just trying to be the best they can, on and off the field." Keri Lumm of Paste said, after the airing of the penultimate episode, "Ted Lasso is the wholesome American hero we need", going on to say "... the landscape of television has felt kind of gloomy, so imagine my surprise when I turned on the TV to Ted Lasso and felt a swelling of a now unfamiliar emotion—hope." And after the finale aired, Lea Palmieri from Decider said: "Every step of the way, Ted Lasso proves to be comforting and entertaining and somehow both a distraction and a reminder that kindness is out there, not just on this fictional show, not just across the pond, but deep in the heart of America too."
output:
The critical response to Season 1 of the Apple TV series "Ted Lasso" was generally positive. Review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes reported an approval rating of 92% based on 74 reviews, with an average rating of 8.2/10. Critics praised the show's warm and winsome nature, as well as its unrelenting optimism and charming performance by Jason Sudeikis. 

Entertainment Weekly gave the series an A−, describing it as a mix of workplace antics, sentimental sports inspiration, and soapy romance that is undeniably winning. Rolling Stone found the series extremely likable throughout, but noted that it leans more towards being a hypothetical comedy rather than an actual one. The Guardian gave it a 2/5 rating, describing it as a show that isn't unwatchably bad but isn't really much of anything, and raised concerns about some of its humor being rooted in questionable stereotypes.

However, as the season progressed, critical appreciation for the show increased. Variety published a review titled "For Your Reconsideration: Ted Lasso," praising the show for chipping away at skepticism and highlighting the satisfaction of spending time with good people trying to be their best. Paste called Ted Lasso the wholesome American hero we need and expressed surprise at feeling hope while watching the show. Decider described Ted Lasso as comforting, entertaining, and a reminder of kindness in America.

Overall, Season 1 of Ted Lasso received generally favorable reviews, with critics appreciating its optimistic and heartwarming approach.

Season 1 of Ted Lasso was rated 92% on Rotten Tomatoes (74 reviews) and 71/100 on Metacritic (21 reviews). Some of the positive reviews described the show as winsome, comforting, entertaining and hopeful. Some viewers enjoyed the good-hearted cheer and optimism the show embodied during the current times of despair and hopelessness. One critic rated the show 2/5 and described it to be " not unwatchably bad".

instruction: Summarize the important contributions of Thomas Edison from this paragraph in a bulleted list.
input: Thomas Alva Edison (February 11, 1847 – October 18, 1931) was an American inventor and businessman. He developed many devices in fields such as electric power generation, mass communication, sound recording, and motion pictures.These inventions, which include the phonograph, the motion picture camera, and early versions of the electric light bulb, have had a widespread impact on the modern industrialized world. He was one of the first inventors to apply the principles of organized science and teamwork to the process of invention, working with many researchers and employees. He established the first industrial research laboratory.

instruction: Help me come up with a cost efficient shopping plan for my family of four.
output:
Certainly! Here's a cost-efficient shopping plan for a family of four:

1. Create a meal plan: Start by planning meals for the week. This will help you avoid unnecessary purchases and reduce food waste.

2. Make a shopping list: Based on your meal plan, create a detailed shopping list. Stick to the list while shopping to avoid impulsive purchases.

3. Compare prices: Before heading to the store, compare prices at different grocery stores or online. Look for discounts, sales, and coupons to save money.

4. Buy in bulk: Consider purchasing non-perishable items in bulk, as it is often more cost-effective. Just make sure you have enough storage space and that the items won't expire before you can use them.

5. Purchase generic brands: Opt for generic or store brands instead of name brands. They are often cheaper and can be of similar quality.

6. Use loyalty programs and rewards: Take advantage of loyalty programs offered by stores. They often provide discounts, coupons, or cashback rewards that can help you save money.

7. Avoid convenience foods: Pre-packaged or convenience foods tend to be more expensive. Opt for fresh ingredients and cook meals from scratch whenever possible.

8. Consider frozen or canned produce: Frozen or canned fruits and vegetables can be a more affordable option, especially when certain items are out of season.

9. Plan for leftovers: Cook larger portions and plan for leftovers. This way, you can utilize the leftovers for another meal, reducing the need to buy additional ingredients.

10. Don't shop when hungry: Shopping on an empty stomach can lead to impulse purchases. Eat before you go to the store to avoid unnecessary spending.

Remember, it's important to stick to your plan and avoid unnecessary purchases. With careful planning and smart shopping, you can save money while still providing nutritious meals for your family.

There is no one shopping plan for any family of four; there are simply too many variables and constraints to consider - and too large a data set - to consider and make a recommendation for a family of four without further context. Some of these variables would include:
- Household income and net worth
- Cost of living
- Living and family arrangements
- Medical conditions

However, there are some basic guidelines which can inform a high percentage of households which rank among the median or most common scenarios. For example, for a family of four in the United States with median income and net worth:

- Set realistic budget and time numbers per month and document
- Document prices for low-cost household staples such as beans, rice, bread, milk, eggs, butter, oil, seasonings in your area by store
- Repeat for fresh fruit and vegetables, meat and fish, ready-to-eat foods, and other items for your family's diet
- Create a shopping list and mark down on your calendar when you will buy each item

There's a first step toward a cost efficient shopping plan for a family of four.

instruction: Describe what it's like in Breckenridge, Colorado
output:
Breckenridge, Colorado is a beautiful mountain town known for its stunning natural scenery and outdoor recreational opportunities. Located in the Rocky Mountains, Breckenridge offers a charming and picturesque setting that attracts visitors from around the world.

One of the main draws of Breckenridge is its world-class ski resort. With over 2,900 acres of skiable terrain and a variety of slopes for all skill levels, it is a paradise for winter sports enthusiasts. The resort features multiple chairlifts, terrain parks, and a vibrant après-ski scene, making it a popular destination for skiers and snowboarders alike.

Beyond skiing and snowboarding, Breckenridge offers a range of other outdoor activities throughout the year. In the warmer months, visitors can enjoy hiking, mountain biking, fishing, and whitewater rafting in the nearby rivers. The town is also home to numerous scenic trails and parks, allowing for leisurely strolls and picnics in nature.

Breckenridge's historic downtown area is another highlight. Lined with colorful Victorian-era buildings, the town exudes a quaint and charming atmosphere. The Main Street is filled with a diverse array of shops, restaurants, art galleries, and boutiques, offering something for everyone. The town is also known for its vibrant arts scene, with various festivals, concerts, and theater performances taking place throughout the year.

For those seeking a more relaxed experience, Breckenridge has a number of spas and wellness centers where visitors can indulge in massages, facials, and other rejuvenating treatments. Additionally, the town hosts several cultural events and festivals that showcase the local heritage and traditions.

Overall, Breckenridge, Colorado is a picturesque mountain town that offers a perfect blend of outdoor adventure, natural beauty, and small-town charm. Whether you are a nature lover, an outdoor enthusiast, or simply looking for a peaceful getaway, Breckenridge has something to offer for everyone.

Breckenridge, Colorado is largely known for its ski resort of the same name. Breckenridge is one of the highest-altitude tourist destinations in the United States, at an elevation of approximately 9600 feet (or 2926 meters). It has a small year-round resident population (a few thousand people), but has millions of visitors every year. Breckenridge Ski Resort operates across five peaks, and includes a chairlift that operates at 12,840 feet (the highest in North America). Although Breckenridge gets more than 300 inches of snow on average each year, it also has abundant sunshine with about 300 days being sunny. Breckenridge has cold winters and moderate summers.
